title: Linked Open Data Session

author: Ivan Herman, World Wide Web Consortium (W3C)

segmentation: Hi so the reason I was asked to spend 5 minutes of your time is to give an idea of what are the thinking we have within W 3C on standardization issue and work around link data.
Put the frame as.
You may have realized, I'm a little bit outsider in the multilingual technology areas.
I come here as a.
Just now we all have that we all love it.
We know what they are.
Note that I have put version numbers for very good reasons because there are a number of these technologies that goes through or have gone through updates sparker 11.
If everything goes well, then it will be published finally next Tuesday.
That's the plan.
RDF 11.
Probably this summer.
Well RDF and RDF, so one one in summer an I presume that all of you know more or less what these guys do.
And we all have that and we all love it.
And we all hate it because this full of problems.
It was already mentioned today and there were some discussions and I'm sure it will come back so I won't go there.
Now our assessment is that what the Community needs is really more on the deployment side.
You know it's the case of half empty or half full.
We can be very proud of having achieved what we have achieved, but if you go a little bit out of our small circle then you realize that you know it's still a question for companies and institutions.
Whether this is something they want to invest in, so.
Use cases are necessary.

More data, more link data because there are some statistics showing that this holding data crowd is cloud is very nice, but the number of links among datasets compared to the number of triples is very low, so it's not really really linked the way we want, etc.
And on the other hand, and also for these purposes, it is very important to convey the message that the underlying technology can be considered as stable.
If we started to add yet another technology on something and yet another tomorrow, we give this impression that this is the continuous development and usings are coming.
So people are waiting, one which will become stable and they can wait and wait.
So this is something we don't want.
So W 3C at this moment does not plan right away on yet another box in the stack because you know, we we think that it's more timely to look at deployment issues rather than doing new specification.
Even if you know people may come up and say well yes, but RDF should be changed because this and this feature is not really good and should make it yes.
Maybe in a few years, but not now.
Instead we look at deployement issues and there are two things that we want to.
Talk about here the vocabulary definitions and usage and outreach to other data format.

So for vocabulary definitions we are talking about how W 3C can have the community to develop vocabularies we are not in position to define vocabularies for everything, even considering the fact that schema.org does not cover everything in spite of what people say.
Sometimes there is a long tail, there is space for lots of new vocabularies, but it's not W 3C that will standardize everything.
Instead, we rely on the community.
We already have community groups at W3C, which are actually a very good forum to develop to get communities together and do the work and develop things.
And we have very good example here.
I picked up the open annotation community group as one, but there are others and and you know they develop vocabularies.
What we would like to do is to extend this practice.
Maybe if we need it at new, new tools for Community groups so that there are stable places where these things.
Can be can be done.
We give them a stable ur eyes which is very important.
So the vocabularies have a stable.
You arise at W3C which we would manage.
We are considering setting up some sort of a registry with metadata on.
The vocabulary is not saying this is good one.

This is not this is not good one because this is not a judgment that you can do but to have a number of issues and number of metadata that characterize the vocabularies and people can then come and choose whatever they want.
We don't know yet what these vocabularies set will be.
This is something that as group has to discuss things like governance, things like version control.
Is it really done?
Is it really properly done?
Who decides at the end of the day on the devolution?
Is it publicly developed so this kind of things?
And here comes yet another issue is how this vocabulary scores in terms of multilinguality, so we will probably come back to you guys because we need.
One or two really good description of is this vocabulary applicable for that.
Another issue is vocabulary validation.
That is not me, that's whoever that is.
So we are.
We are discussing the possibility and I am I am conscious to be.

You know all conditional here because it's not yet decided is to help to validate datasets against vocabularies and you have to realize if you think about the semantics of RDF and OWL and RDF schema, those are not good for validation.
Those are not done for validation, even if people sometimes think they are.
And we need a possibility to highlight deployement of linked data by giving them tools and approaches to.
You know to check the quality of the data.
Now there are various approaches here and as I said we think of setting up a workshop.
Probably sometimes early autumn and probably at MIT.
But all these are our plans and of course.
Here is another question.
How the hell would I validate the quality of a vocabulary from Multilinguality POV?
I don't have the answer you guys tell me, but you know validation can be structural, can be against the data types, but OK. How do I validate from this point of view?
Now, one thing we have to realize that there is much more data today on the web out there used.
That there are linked open data on the web.
That's again something that we have to face.
Again, it's the issue of half empty or half full.
There are data out there in all kinds of different formats, from PDF to XML, from pure text files to.
I don't know what you name it and applications rely on that API rely on that an you know we have to deal with it.
There is currently a kind of a disconnect.
If you look at the web community that web developers community who develop all those beautiful sexy websites, they use data.
They very rarely used linked open data.
Let's face it, they use all kinds of other data and so.
What do we do about that?
We can't just ignore that type of data which is out there.
So we do have a workshop coming up in London in April, which is open data on the web.
Know that it's not necessarily open link data.
We got quite a number of submissions already and we don't know yet because we are in the reviewing process, but we hope to have issues on people dealing with all kinds of data.
And what do we do about that?
Of course.
What do you do with Multilinguality in the non RDF word?
I know that this section is on Elodie, but you know what do you do with the other stuff?
How do you check that?
How do you create it?
You know how?
Is there any way to manage that properly?
I I don't have the answers.
But we have to face this is this is an issue.
That's it, I think I got my 5 minutes.
